class MoleculeTools(atms=None)

Bases: object

ChkAnm(molref)

Check no total angular momentum is present along the linear path connecting molref to self. 0 = sum_i atmass_i(molref x self)

FitCylinder(atomlist, guessVector=None)
FitHelicalAxis(atomlist, rotmatrix, center, radius, rightHelix)

Param rotmatrix:Rotation matrix(new, old) which rotate the system in order that Z is the helical Axis Param center:Center of the Helical Axis Param radius:radius of the Helical Axis Param rightHelix:right(P) Helix:True or left(M) Helix:False Return:return the error, the pitch and the phase of the Helical Axis

RMSD(mol2)

Calculate the Root Mean Square Deviation: Square root of the mean of the square of the distances between the atoms of two molecules

get_Rsquare_matrix(weight=None, atomlist=None)

Rsquare matrix is a matrix whose elements are given by: Rquare_ {alphabeta}= sum_i R_ {ialpha} R_ {ibeta} weight_i where R_ {ialpha} = coord[i, alpha] - centroid Param weight:list of weight of size natoms Param atomlist:list of atoms

get_center_of_charge(atomlist=None)
get_center_of_mass(atomlist=None)
get_centroid(weight=None, atomlist=None)

Param weight:list of weight of size natoms Param atomlist:list of atoms

get_moment_of_charge(atomlist=None)

similar to moment of inertia but with the charge instead of the mass

get_moment_of_inertia(atomlist=None)
moi_ {alphabeta} = sum_i m_i[r^2_i delta_ {alphabeta} - r_ {ialpha} r_ {ibeta}]

= (sum_i m_i r^2_i)delta_ {alphabeta} - Rsquare_ {alpha beta}

moi = sum_i m_i[vec {r} _i cdot vec {r} _i identity - vec {r} _i otimes vec {r} _i]

getatomtype(atnum)

Get the atoms of atomic number atnum in the molecule

isLinear()

Guess if a molecule is linear

match(mol2, improper_rotation=True, scale=None)

Match the coordinates between two molecules The output rotation, scale, translation give the following transformation: mol1' = sR*mol1 + trans = mol2 param improper_rotation:if yes, allow for improper rotation if they give a better match param scale:use this scaling if given, otherwise, get the best scaling (1) HORN, B. J Opt Soc Am A 1987, 4, 629-642. (2) Coutsias, E.; Seok, C.; Dill, K. J. Comput. Chem. 2004, 25, 1849-1857.

match_kneller(molref, scale=None)

Match the coordinates between two molecules

  1. Kneller, G. Mol. Simulation 1991, 7, 113-119.

    The output rotation, scale, translation give the following transformation: mol = sR*molref + trans

match_reflexion(mol2)

Match the coordinates between two molecules using a reflexion instead of rotation

Get the number of atoms of atomic number atnum in the molecule

in_box(points, box3d)

box3d = np array of the shape (8,3) with coordinates in the clockwise order. first the bottom plane is considered then the top one. points = array of points with shape (N, 3).

Returns the indices of the points array which are outside the box3d adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21037241/how-to-determine-a-point-is-inside-or-outside-a-cube

in_box2(points, box)

box3d = np array of the shape (8,3) with coordinates in the clockwise order. first the bottom plane is considered then the top one. points = array of points with shape (N, 3).

Returns the indices of the points array which are outside the box3d adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21037241/how-to-determine-a-point-is-inside-or-outside-a-cube

transformation.tools.Quaternions module

class Quaternion(ps, pv)

Bases: object

Reflection(r)

Do the r'= Q r Q transformation where Q is a unit imaginary quaternion and r and r' are vectors. Correspond to a reflection through the plane perpendicular to the vector given by the imaginary part of the quaternion

Rotate(r)

Do the r'= Q r Q* transformation where Q is a unit quaternion and r and r' are vectors. Correspond to a counter-clockwise rotation

conjugate()
get_reflection_matrix()

if a quaternion is a unit imaginary quaternion, it can represent a reflection.

get_rotation_matrix()

if a quaternion is a unit quaternion, it can represent a counter-clockwise rotation.

mult(q)
norm()
normalized()
print_rotQuaternion()

Q = cos(theta/2) + sin(theta/2) * n where n is a unit vector along the rotation axis We want theta from -pi -> pi But theta, n gives the same quaternion as -theta, -n Therefore, theta:0 -> pi, theta/2:0 -> pi/2 cos > 0 while sin > 0 If cos < 0, Q' = -Q:correspond to have theta + 2pi We can allow theta to be -pi -> pi if we restrict n to be in 4 octant instead of the 8 octant.

reciprocal()

transformation.tools.Rotations module

class Euler_Rotation(angles, axes=(2, 0, 2), convention='intrinsic', deg=False)

Bases: object

Define a rotation by individual rotation around three axes In the "intrinsic" convention, the rotations are around the moving axes In the "extrinsic" convention, the rotations are around the fixed axes

get_angle_axis(deg=False)

Get the rotation of an angle theta around an axis of rotation Angle:0->pi Param:deg:angle is in degrees instead of radians

get_rotation_matrix()

return the rotation matrix For intrinsic:rot = axes[0](angles[0]) * axes[1](angles[1]) * axes[2](angles[2]) For extrinsic:rot = axes[2](angles[2]) * axes[1](angles[1]) * axes[0](angles[0]) Rotate the lab frame to go the mol frame = U_lab,mol

class Rotation_frame(lab, mol)

Bases: object

Get the rotation angle between two frames

get_angle_axis(deg=False)

Get the rotation of an angle theta around an axis of rotation to go from laboratory to molecular frame Angle:0->pi Param:deg:angle is in degrees instead of radians

get_angles_zxz(deg=False)

Calculated the alpha, beta, gamma angles in the zx'z'' (or ZXZ) convention return:alpha, beta, gamma angles where beta is the angle between the z-axis and the Z-axis and range from 0 -> pi where gamma is the angle between the x-axis and the line of nodes and range from -pi -> pi where alpha is the angle between the X-axis and the line of nodes and range from -pi -> pi The line of nodes is given by(Z cross z) Param:deg:alpha, beta, gamma are in degrees instead of radians

get_angles_zyz(deg=False)

Calculated the alpha, beta, gamma angles in the zy'z'' (or ZYZ) convention return:alpha, beta, gamma angles where beta is the angle between the z-axis and the Z-axis and range from 0 -> pi where gamma is the angle between the y-axis and the line of nodes and range from -pi -> pi where alpha is the angle between the Y-axis and the line of nodes and range from -pi -> pi The line of nodes is given by(Z cross z) Param:deg:alpha, beta, gamma are in degrees instead of radians

get_rotation_matrix()

return the rotation matrix from laboratory to molecular frame

get_angle_axis(rotmat, deg=False)

Get the rotation of an angle theta around an axis of rotation Angle:0->pi Param:deg:angle is in degrees instead of radians

get_arotation_matrix(axes, angle, deg=False)

Get the rotation matrix around on of the axes Param:axes:one of(0, 1, 2) for (x, y, z) Param angle:0.0 -> pi counter-clockwise rotation Param:deg:angle is in degrees instead of radians

orient_from(ini_vector, fin_vector, deg=False)
Give the angle and axis of rotation to orient an object starting in the 'ini_vector' direction

toward the "fin_vector" direction

:param:ini_vector:initial vector direction :param:fin_vector:final vector direction

The axis of rotation is the vector perpenticular to ini_vector and fin_vector angle:0.0 -> pi counter-clockwise rotation Param:deg:angle is in degrees instead of radians
